title: iain-macwhirter-fans-blame-footballs-greed
story: Im sure even the poundbn bung being offered to the Shameful Six in the English game would not have enticed the Maryhill Magyars into deserting their country and community. Small town big dreams.I gave up watching football years ago, partly out of revulsion at how it has become a playground for plutocrats, but mainly because its become pretty boring. Id rather watch the dads playing park football ndash theres a lot more goals for a start. So I was supremely indferent to the news that some English clubs with more money than sense had decided to join a breakaway European Super League. Better off without them.However, the mega-stushie in the beautul game has now taken on an unexpected political signicance. The future king has joined with the Prime Minister to condemn this European League of Greed. Boris Johnson has promised to blitz the ESL with ldquoa legislative bomb.Im not entirely sure the government can prevent these foreign-owned private businesses crossing continents, but never mind. This is a Red Wall issue. Sir Keir Starmer has also cried foul and called on the government to take back control, asthis were another dimension of Brexit. MACWHIRTER:Alba needs a U-turn after its car crash campaignThe European Super League has nothing whatever to do with the European Union, but it does with something underlying it: globalisation. It is part of the relentless march of capitalist expansion across national borders, leaving the little people behind. And there has been a hint of Brexit in the way commentators have condemned the mega clubs for betraying their country and community. Pundits on the left have been sounding like Nigel Farage wondering whatever happened to patriotism and loyalty to ones own.It is all about money, of course. The founding clubs will reportedly share pound billion courtesy of JP Morgan, which is one of the mega banks now financing Big Footie. This is to help them adjust to the rarefied atmosphere of global football, and is absolutely not intended as a bribe, or to buy the lads a drink. It is also to cover their vast debts.Fans and football governing bodies like UEFA are furious. The left-behind clubs stand to lose a heap of money by not being included in this European Super League. Politicians and football celebrities like Gary Lineker are attacking the breakaway clubs for disrespecting the fans and for polluting the Peoples Game with filthy lucre.There is, it has to be said, just a hint of hypocrisy in this outrage from wealthy ex-players and managers. British football is hardly a model of affordable community sport. The Premier league is all about money ndash mainly TV cash ndash which has been used to pay ludicrous sums to the primping prima donnas of the pitch. The main reason the sports personalities and clubs are worried now is that some of their money will be creamed off by the super leaguers.Defenders of the ESL say its just the way the game is going in the age of globalisation. They claim that many of the big clubs, far from minting it, are actually dicing with bankruptcy. This is partly because of Covid, but mainly because of the huge debts they have incurred trying to maintain their standing in the world and keep their fans happy. To survive, the top clubs need to cash in on that global status. Playing a wet Wednesday in Stoke doesnt make it.READMORE MACWHIRTER:Sturgeonrsquos border problem could possibly kill Yes vote stone deadThe fans arent entirely innocent bystanders here. Theyve wanted success above all ndash silverware in the boardroom. To quote Bill Shankly: ldquoIf you are first youre firstyoure second youre nothing. To win nowadays is hugely expensive. Superstar Lionel Messis contract with FC Barcelona is worth over poundm a year. This may help explain why the world-famous club is in pound.bn in debt.Of course, theres a simple answer to that cash flow problem: just dont pay them. But that doesnt work in the global sports marketplace, apparently. From the point of view of clubs like Manchester United, who apparently have more fans in India than in England, it is all about giving their viewers what they want. It is no more objectionable, they say, than rock bands performing in mega stadiums on world tours. No one says the Rolling Stones are abandoning their fans and following the money.If people keep paying, the Super League will probably happen, sooner or later, whatever the politicians say. As for Scottish football ndash well, nothing to see here since no team in Scotland is remotely in contention. Which in many ways is a very good thing. Every few years there are rumours about Rangers and Celtic plotting to join the English Premier league on the grounds that they cant afford to continue in the small pond of Scottish football. But it never seems to happen.This could be an opportunity for Scottish football to go precisely the other way: become a sport which was more about local fellowship than global finance. Be more like the Jags. Partick Thistle is one of a small but growing number of Scottish clubs that are owned by their supporters. Mind you that was because of the generosity of the late Colin Weir, who essentially bought the club to give it to the fans. I doubtthe American Glazer family, who own Man U, will do likewise.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: coronavirus-glasgow-study-finds-cheap-tool-improve-vaccine-efficiency
story: The largest study of its kindfound physical activity cuts the risk of dying from infectious diseases such asCovid- by  per cent and reduces thechance of catching viruses by  per cent.Researchers said a -week physical activity programme before vaccination,could result in  to  per cent more effective immunisation.Glasgow Caledonian University looked at , worldwide epidemiological studies published between January  and April , involving adults over .There was no reliable data specically for Covid-so the team studiedsimilar infectious diseases of the same family.: European medicines agency find possible link between Johnson and Johnsonvaccine and rare blood clotsThe research found that -minutes of activity five days a week or -minutes per week that gets you slightly out of breath such as walking, running, cycling and strengthening exercises can have a massive impact on immunity to infectious diseases such as Covid-.Professor Sebastien Chastin, lead author,said they found that physical activity ldquostrengthens the first line of defence of the human immune system and a higher concentration of immune cells.ldquoThis research is hugely signicant and could help to cut the number people contracting COVID- and dying from it."It is the first piece of research that proves regular physical activity protects you against infectious disease.ldquoWe found that regular exercise where you get out of breath boosts your immunity to infectious disease by  per cent and it increases the number of immune cells in the body in the first line of defence which is the mucosal layer of antibodies."These cells are responsible for identying foreign agents in the body without depressing the rest of the immune system so itrsquos perfectly safe and protects you against infectious disease.ldquoWe also found thatyou add physical activity to your vaccination programme it increases the potency of the vaccination.: Coronavirus Scotland:  new Covid cases in  hours and two deaths"We are recommending a -weeks physical activity programme before vaccination which could result in  to  per cent more effective immunisation."This is not a panacea but another cheap tool we can use to protect the public."While there was no research directly linking the level offitness with outcomes, Prof Chastin said it wasreasonable to assume that the fitter you are the more likely you are to be able to fight an infection of any kind.The findings have been sent to the Scottish Government and other governments around world as well as public health experts and healthcare professionals.Professor Chastin advised the public to build regular physical activity into their weekly routine to help them fight off the COVID- virus.He added: ldquoThe clear message is stay active ndash itrsquos not only good for your mental and general health but we now have the proof that it is also good for boosting your immunity."The research paper,lsquoEffects of regular physical activity on the immune system, vaccination and risk of community acquired infectious disease in the general population: Systematic review and meta-analysisrsquo has been published in the Sports Medicine journal.

title: scottish-green-election-strategy-accused-undermining-independence
story: The claim came fromAlex Salmondspro-independence Alba Party,which has urged its supporters to vote SNP in constituencies and Alba on the regional list in order to maximise the number of pro-independence MSPs.Senior Alba candidate Tasmina Ahmed-Sheikh, a former SNP MP, also suggested the Greens were not being honest with voters and taking them for ldquofools.Although they have yet to come close to doing it, the Scottish Greens havelong hoped to wina constituency in Scotland, emulatingthe success of Green MP Caroline Lucas, who has held the Brighton Pavilion seat at Westminster since .As well as standing on the eight regional lists, where they have won all their MSPs since , the Scottish Greens are alsocontesting  first-past-the-post seats this year.At the  Scottish election, the Greens stood in just three constituencies- Coatbridge  Chryston, Edinburgh Central and Glasgow Kelvin.In Coatbridge and Kelvin, the SNP candidate still won relatively easily.However in Edinburgh Central, the Greens arguably help the Tories to victory.Then Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson won with a majority ofjust  over the SNP after Green candidate Alison Johnstone polled , votes.:Tom Gordon -Something doesnt smell right about the Alba PartyThis year, Ms Johnstone is again standing in Edinburgh Central, while Green Laura Moodie is standing inmarginal Galloway  West Dumfries, where Tory incumbent Finlay Carson is defending a majority of , over the SNP.The Greens are also standing in three other seats where the SNP majority over Labour in  was under,- Aberdeen Central, Cowdeneath and Glasgow Provan.Scottish Greens co-leader Patrick Harvie is also standing again in Glasgow Kelvin, where he came , behind the SNP winner in , although that is effectively a fight between two Yes candidates.Ms Ahmed-Sheikh, Albarsquos top-ranked candidate on the Central Scotland list, told the recent Through a Scottish Prism podcast that it would be ldquoremiss of her not to raise the Green issue.She said: ldquoThe Green candidates standing in this election are not helping the cause of independence when they stand against the SNP MSP candidates in the constituencies.ldquoItrsquos all very well for members of the Scottish Greens to cast us aside as an irrelevance and not necessary [because] theyrsquoll secure the independence majority.ldquoTheyrsquore actively working against that by standing against SNP candidates in constituency seats the SNP would definitely win but for, perhaps, votes that will be lost to the Green party.ldquoSo at the very least, in this election, I think political parties should speak with some honesty about what the maths actually mean, and what the votes actually mean.ldquoBecause the people of Scotland donrsquot button up the back or from any other direction. They understand whatrsquos going on. People should not try and make fools of the voting public.Ms Ahmed-Sheikh seized on the Edinburgh Central result of  as an example of Greens inadvertently helpinga Unionist candidate win.She said: ldquoWhat a triumph that was for the independence movement, securing the election of Baroness Ruth Davidson. That speaks for itself. All the maths is there.:Patrick Harvie raises Prince Philips extreme wealth and privilege at Holyrood tributeA spokesperson for the Scottish Greens said: ldquoWersquove shown a vote for the Scottish Greens delivers progressive policies such as a ban on evictions during the pandemic, free bus travel for young people and free school dinners for all primary school children.ldquoWersquove shown a vote for the Scottish Greens delivers a pro-independence majority. And a vote for the Scottish Greens delivers urgent action on the climate emergency.ldquoAlba might want to get a record of delivery and some policies before claiming to understand the voting public.

title: scotlands-colleges-facing-indefinite-three-day-strikes
story: Staff are also being balloted on action short of walk-outs that could see them mark assessments but not enter or share results through their institutionrsquos systems.If voted through, the move by the EIS Further Education Lecturersrsquo Associationwould affect thousands of students and plunge graduations into uncertainty.The row erupted after college representatives were accused of seeking to replace lecturer posts with ldquoinstructor assessor positions.:Scottish colleges in chaos as lecturers go on strikeUnion leaders said the Colleges Scotland Employersrsquo Associationhad refused to raty one section of a proposed national role profile that sets out the core professional responsibilities considered to be ldquounique to a lecturerrsquos job.They claimed disagreement had arisen because employers wish to use non-lecturing staff to fulfill these responsibilities.EIS-FELA bosses said failure to protect lecturer roles would deprive staff of vital class preparation time and remove the need for them to be registered with the General Teaching Council for Scotland .This week has already seen a deterioration in the situation, with employees on Wednesdaypreparing to continue a strike as they bid to force a climbdown.The CSEA said the allegation that it was seeking to replace lecturers was ldquounfounded and called the action unnecessary.A message of solidarity and support from Larry Flanagan, @EISUnion General Secretary.#CollegesNeedLecturers pic eWYcqPWIt added that the only outstanding issue still to be finalised was around the wording of the national role profile.CSEA leaders also said they had requested that discussions continue to gain further ldquoclarication on how the profile would be used and rejected accusations they had refused to ldquoraty an agreement.But John Kelly, EIS-FELA national salaries convener and a lecturer in business at West College Scotland, insisted the risks to further education were grave.:Colleges and universities in call for extra millions to plug deficitsldquoMy current contract includes a set period of time for class preparation but the contract for an instructor does not, he explained.ldquoFor learning and teaching to be of value we require preparation and planning.ldquoItrsquos shocking in terms of work-load for staff ndash they might be told they have to do their preparation in the evening or over the weekend ndash but also from the perspective of students. If therersquos no time set aside for class preparation, the quality of education on offer just plummets. Instructors also have lower salaries.AGENDA:Colleges vital role in breaking down barriersldquoWersquove also been campaigning for compulsory registration of lecturers with the General Teaching Council for Scotlandand that is now happening. We signed an agreement with Colleges Scotland in  which ensures that lecturers will have to be registered with the GTCS in the way school teachers are, which is a good thing. And then this [replacing lecturers with instructors] comes in.ldquoInstructors will not have to be registered with the GTCS and I can really see a two-tier system developing in further education in which some courses are taught by registered lecturers and others arenrsquot.Calling for ministers to intervene, he added: ldquoAn indefinite, three-day weekly strike at colleges is a possibility. The terms of our ballot mean, in effect, that it could happen. I would hope it doesnrsquot come to that but goodwill amongst staff is now draining away fast.If yoursquore a college student in Scotland wondering what the strikes are about, herersquos a very short explainer # pic MlYkAgkJMatt Crilly, NUS Scotland President, branded the situation ldquoscandalous and said an ldquoimmediate resolution was needed.ldquoThe EIS-FELA has refused repeated requests to suspend the strikes while meaningful discussions carry on ndash national industrial action is wholly unnecessary.Addressing an NUS Scotland-hosted online debate, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said it was ldquonot acceptable to get rid of lecturers and re-hire iniduals to do the same job ldquoon lesser conditions.She added: ldquoI am very clearly saying to employers, lsquoget round the table and get this resolved.rsquoStudent Grant MacKay, outside Glasgow Kelvin Collegersquos East End Campus, fears the dispute could hit his plans for a university place.CASE STUDYBy Lauren GilmourA studentfears he will not complete his course on time due to the ongoing strike involving lecturers at his college.Grant MacKay, , who is studying for his HNC in Working with Communities at Glasgow Kelvin College, has raised concerns that he might not finish his course on time to take up his place at the University of the West of Scotland in Septemberno agreement is met.He said: ldquoIrsquove already put in a formal complaint to my college regarding the time left. ldquoBy my calculations, therersquos only seven weeks left after the strike today.ldquoWe only have seven weeks left and that takes us over the time needed to teach the unit and to do the assessment.Grant claims that the college is currently exploring the option of extending the term by an additional four weeks to cover the time lost to strikes which have been called by the EIS union, which represents the lecturers over a dispute surrounding their job description.:Fears over rush to cuts at universities and collegesHe added: ldquoIrsquove got an official stamped document for my council tax exemption which states this course ends on June . My funding ends on June  so Irsquove asked the college: are they going to pay my student loan and my extra bursary for that month that potentially I have to stay on ldquoIrsquove raised concerns to the college that part of my offer to university is that I complete all of my modules and units.ldquoI would like a guarantee that regardless of what happens that we pass our course or HNC so that we can get to university.The union claims they are being replaced with less qualied tutors who are not part of the nationally agreed pay scale and terms and conditions as set out by Colleges Scotland, the governing body for further education.EIS claim the move would have negative consequences for students and would create a two-tier system of education, as not all students would have the opportunity to be taught by a professionally trained lecturer.COMMENT:Flexible and creative, colleges are key to Scotlandrsquos futureA spokeswoman for Glasgow Kelvin College confirmed that they share studentsrsquo concerns about the impact of the dispute and that measures are being put in place to support them.She said: ldquoGlasgow Kelvin College echoes the concerns of its students and is disappointed that the EIS FELA industrial action remains unresolved despite a consensus being reached between the trade union and the national Employers Association on the key issues of this dispute.ldquoColleges are working to do all they can so that students are not disadvantaged by the impact of the pandemic or by the current strike days and proposed industrial action.ldquoThe College fully appreciates that all students have their inidual challenges and we urge them to engage with their lecturing and support staff to access educational, financial and wellbeing support. Students are reminded that there is a wide range of support services available at Glasgow Kelvin College to help them at this very dficult time.

title: investors-click-digital-xtra-funds-bold-vision-learning-scotland
story: SCOTLAND may be a relatively small country, but it has a real opportunity to be a global leader in the digital economy. We have the drive, the knowledge, the skills and also the ambition.One area where we could improve, however, is education. Specically, our young people need to become enthused by, and engaged with, the ious opportunities technology offers.If they see exciting and worthwhile careers are available in tech and go on to fulfil these roles, it will build the critical talent pool required.Digital Xtra Fund is targeting exactly this goal. A Scotland-wide charity, it is increasing interest in computing and technology among those aged  and under by supporting extracurricular tech activities that inspire young people to follow this path.The Fund has been highly successful and continues to grow. It is winning new financial support and expanding its ambitions further to the point where it is now seriously contemplating a future where there is a tech club in every school or community in the country. ldquoWe have new partnerships in place and a new role within the Fund, says Kraig Brown, the Fundrsquos Partnerships and Development Manager. ldquoItrsquos all very positive.In a major boost, the Fund has most recently partnered with new Scottish tech investment company Chroma Ventures, which has donated pound,. This means when the Fundrsquos annual grants are announced in June, it will award pound, rather than the pound, originally announced.The charity is also hiring a Community and Grants Officer to help take it to the next level. This person will focus on fostering collaboration between industry and grant recipients.They will also help those receiving financial awards to understand concepts such as ethics in technology, how to use tech as a force for good, as well as the importance of meta-skills ndash skills to create, collaborate and empathise with others ndash alongside technical skills. Kraig Brown says the new role is part of a wider strategy to help industry enthuse youngsters about tech and develop their understanding of the digital world.ldquoWe want to get more professionals in front of young people talking about their careers. If young people can connect what theyrsquore learning to these jobs, it will help exponentially long-term.One example he gives occurred during a recent online session he attended at Heart of Midlothian FCrsquos Innovation Centre, a community-based initiative offering courses to help participants learn digital skills.ldquoThere was a User Experience Designer from Sky who was giving participants some really useful feedback on things like how their apprsquos buttons could stand out better and where the back button should be to make it more intuitive.ldquoI think these types of interactions are hugely valuable because it relates the learning to lsquoreal lersquo while also informing young people what a UX Designer does.This doesnrsquot happen enough, but this new role will encourage and facilitate more of these interactions and share examples of best practice.Kraig is also delighted with the additional funding provided by Chroma Ventures.ldquoIt made an immediate impact. It means we can now disburse pound, this year ndash thatrsquos fantastic. It also puts us back on track with where we were pre-Covid Irsquom proud of that too.This increased confidence is enabling the Fund to think more about how Scotland can become a global tech leader. Kraig would like Digital Xtra Fund to lead on developing a network of lsquoTechspacesrsquo for every school or community across the country. Modelled after Makerspaces ndash these would be informal learning spaces designed and dedicated to giving young people the opportunity to get creativewith tech.ldquoThey would be fun, safe spaces where children and young people could get hands-on and learn about tech. They could discover and explore at their own pace while trying out ious coding s or kit. The learning is informal, but educators and volunteers would provide lessons and structure just like all the other extracurricular activities we support. However, there isnrsquot the stress of a test or essay at the end which puts a lot of young people off trying computing when they get to Secondary.ldquoTechspaces would also operate outwith the curriculum meaning they would be flexible and could more easily involve industry volunteers. Non-curriculum programmes such as lsquodo your:bitrsquo from the Micro:bit Educational Foundation, iDEA Badges, or Apps for Good ndash which are proven to engage young people ndash could be easily incorporated as therersquod be no set curriculum. This would give participants opportunities to try new things and essentially play around without a fear of failure.This approach addresses several of the challenges facing Computer Science in schools. ldquoFirst and foremost, there arenrsquot enough Computer Science teachers in Secondary Schools and the ones who are in place have to keep an eye on the curriculum.ldquoAt the Primary level, teachers are already often at capacity so asking them to include more during class time isnrsquot always viable, not to mention the training involved. Evenwe overcame this, many schools donrsquot have the kit or budget and eventhey do, it is often restricted by firewalls set by the Council.ldquoWe need make the idea of playing with technology exciting and not stressful. This could be done in the classroom ndash there are some brilliant examples of this across Scotland ndash but there are many challenges doing it that way and we need to start winning young people over more quickly.Kraig is under no illusions the magnitude of this vision. With , schools in Scotland, it would require signicant investment. However, he does not believe this all should come from the Government either.ldquoDigital Xtra Fund has successfully brought industry and Government together to award pound, over the past five years. Yes, education is ultimately the responsibility of the Government, but it is industry that needs this to happen and will directly benefit from an increased talent pool. As such, we need to work together. I believe this is the easiest and quickest way to create a generation of inventors and innovators to make Scotland a global leader in the digital economy.www.digitalxtrafund.scot--------------------------------------Scots entrepreneurs share fundrsquos aim to inspire youngstersTHERE is no doubt that the Digital Xtra Fundrsquos vision of digital learning is a highly challenging and ambitious one. But Kraig Brown believes in thinking big. His mantra is thatthere is a will, there is a way.Bringing Chroma Ventures on board is undoubtedly a big step forward. The company was established in Scotland earlier this year by entrepreneurs Paddy Burns and Chris van der Kuyl.Pictured left, Paddy Burns, Chris van der Kuyl and Gavin Anderson of tech investment firm Chroma VenturesIt is the investment arm of J Studios, the multiple award winning video games company best known for developing Minecraft for Microsoft, Sony and Nintendo games consoles.It shares the fundrsquos ethos that inspiring young people to understand and to create with technology is essential to the future well-being of Scotland.The donation is one of the biggest the charity has received to this date.As part of the companyrsquos new commitment to the fund its Principal Paddy Burns, who is also Chief Executive of J Studios, will now join as a trustee, bringing new thinking and strengthening the charityrsquos entrepreneurial credentials.Kraig Brown says that he is delighted about the tie-up. ldquoLike many charities,  was full of uncertainty for us.ldquoThis support from Chroma Ventures has enabled us to continue supporting educators and young people at the same level as previous years. At a time when many in the third sector are struggling, this is important as it builds confidence among our grant recipients, stakeholders and other industry partners that we will consistently support talent in Scotlandrsquos tech sector.And Paddy Burns comments: ldquoTechnology is a thread that runs through my own back story and the sort of initiatives delivered by Digital Xtra Fund resonated strongly. I firmly believe that improving digital skills throughout Scotland can lead to le changing opportunities for young people across the country.Article in association with Digital Xtra Fund.

title: janey-godley-tory-sleaze-back-like-s-club-7-rebooted
story: David Cameron is in the news, apparently, a lobbying sleaze has erupted after it was discovered he texted the chancellor Rishi Sunak on behalf of Greensill Capital.Turns out Cameron also lobbied the NHS on behalf of the company as soon as the pandemic hit. Nothing to see here eh  Who hasnrsquot texted their mate to let them know therersquos a big sale at the Co-op and their own brand pizzas are going three for a pound Who knew rich men would gather around the fringes of a plague and figure out how to make the most money from the panic-stricken public  Whilst you and I were drawing up a plan for banana bread and toilet roll, apparently the Westminster well connected, were sitting around the table dishing out the best cards of the deck to their mates, whilst laughing off trips to Barnard castle.:Janey Godley: Why do union flag-waving patriots think they can decide who can and cant grieve Hastily made PPE companies were set up, heavily funding ministerrsquos families with their friends becoming rich shareholders emerged as you were isolating your family, trying to organise furlough payments and drawing up a plan to home school the wee ones. Normal behaviour.Tory Sleaze is back like S Club  rebooted but this time actually wearing a robberrsquos mask and with well-connected offshore holdings.Small businesses are on their knees, shops are closing, tourism has collapsed butyou are lucky enough to have an EX-PM on your Whatsapp group then your future will be ok.No doubt like every other Tory sleaze scandal, it will wash off like suspicious grass and not even leave a stain.The double standards and hypocrisy are staggering,you see what Nicola Sturgeon went through recently in Scotland when she was hauled before a committee and grilled for eight hours over a missing calendar meeting by the Scottish branch managers of the Tory party, yoursquod be right in thinking part-time linesman Douglas Ross would all over this Greensill debacle with his tartan sword of truth demanding ministerial answers. But we know that wonrsquot happen, they have policies to quickly create for the forthcoming election, as they pinned all their hopes on crushing Sturgeon over Salmond and that fish pie collapsed.Even a Tory MP has spoken out explaining that the hard-won electoral gains against Labour in England will be on a shoogly pegthey donrsquot clear up the Greensill affair.I have the feeling it will fade into the publicrsquos memory some folk have a way of reconciling their morals when it comes to standing by their prime minister. The ldquoOne where Jenner Arcuri got paid for nothing episode of lsquoFriends at Number rsquo went without a hitch. People readily accepted that Boris had a loud American woman who hung about with him, got taxpayers money and was heavily involved in far-right  groups. Hersquos a manrsquos man, a blonde buffoon, the guy that lsquogets the burdsrsquo and so whatit upsets some left-wing snowflakes  Hersquos Boris.I donrsquot knowthe Greensill sleaze will run, on the Andrew Marr show when confronted about the details, environmental secretary George Eustice explained that it was lsquoacceptablersquo and Cameron worked within the rules and defended him. So thatrsquos that then, no more to be said  We shall see how it develops as the Scottish branch of Tories face an election very soon.:Janey Godley: Drinking alcohol in parks should be banned for everyone or open to allMeanwhile, these testy subjects donrsquot filter down fully into the public conscience, when these news articles are posted to Facebook, a lot of the voting public see it as boring and not really lsquotheir businessrsquo so Bunty and her pals pay no attention, as it doesnrsquot really affect them ldquoIt always happens, all politicians are liars, can you post some more funny cat videos If the general news channels arenrsquot holding these subjects up enough to be scrutinised then itrsquos down to people to keep bringing these points up.I try, but on Twitter am busy fighting with people who canrsquot stop watching me but keep telling me am not funny.Other than government scandals, the next major fall out I believe will be the lack of mental health services for people emerging from lockdown, which,the news is anything to go by, that will be pretty soon. The lockdown roadmap says we should be on a windy Scottish beach by July, sitting in an Arran knit cardigan pretending its better than Spain. Families are looking forward to getting close to freezing Lochs and picnic days out, I am one of them. It will feel like a genuine luxury but therersquos more to easing lockdown than getting to see your pals.People who have lost loved ones but not able to share that grief with family, folk living alone and the general mental instability that Covid has inflicted on the nation should be fully funded and addressed as soon as possible.The mental health services across the UK and in where I live in Scotland have fallen, whether we can blame the overburdened NHS or Covid rules, I donrsquot know, but I do know therersquos going to be a huge surge of people relying on the NHS for its mental well being once we unclench from the fear of the virus and it needs to be addressed as serious as the vaccination rollout.:Janey Godley: I have decided to launch my own political partyPeople need mental support and now. This isnrsquot something a quick chat with a GP can sort, you canrsquot have a nation isolated, terried and hiding in their houses for over a year without some sort of emotional backlash. I am hoping the money will be provided for these services as quick as they found cash to pay for the nuclear warheadrsquos renewal. Maybe some Tory ministers can lobby the PM about this issue I suspect some Tory minister will soon set up a counselling company, hire their unqualied pals and sell shares to cash in on our sadness, am not even joking, I think that might already be happening.

title: covid-scotland-book-free-covid-test-even-dont-symptoms
story: It comes as the First Minister has announced araft of changes to coronavirus restrictionsfrom Monday, including the provision of rapid lateral flow tests.Speaking about the changes from Monday April , Nicola Sturgeon said people who have been shielding canto work,they can not work from home.In addition, children who have been shielding canto school.:Nicola Sturgeons Scotland lockdown update:  things you need to knowAll shops will also be able to reopen from Monday, along with close-contact services, such as beauty parlours.People will be able to go into premises to collect takeaways, rather than having to get them from a serving hatch, or at the door.Meanwhile, cafes, pubs and restaurants will be able to reopen, with alcohol able to be served outside from Monday ndash when people can meet outside in groups of up to six from six dferent households.But in indoor hospitality, Ms Sturgeon said the ldquogreater risks would mean alcohol can still not be served, although pubs, cafes and restaurants can open till pm.Six people can meet indoors in hospitality settings, but must be from two households.Ms Sturgeon also confirmed that people without symptoms will be able to book rapid lateral flow tests which canresults within half an hour.Ms Sturgeon urged people to consider using these before travelling to Scotlandrsquos island communities ndash where coronavirus numbers tend to be lower.With many islands having ldquovery, very low rates of Covid, Ms Sturgeon said anyone travelling to one was being encouraged to take two tests ndash one three days before travelling and one on the day of departure.From Monday you can travel anywhere across Britain for any purpose.If anyone tests positive for the virus, they can then book a more sensitive PCR test to confirm the result ahead, and can safely manage their plans accordingly.You can order free packs of rapid lateral flow tests to be sent to your homeyou live in Scotland, are over  and:You should not use this serviceyou have:A rapid lateral flow testpack contains  tests.You can only order one pack per household each day.Speaking at a Covid briefing in Edinburgh yesterday,Ms Sturgeon said: "Two weeks ago, I indicated that we would make lateral flow tests available to anyone in Scotland who wants one."I can confirm, therefore, that lateral flow testing will be available to anyone in Scotland from April ."You can order lateral flow tests online for delivery to your home and you can find information on how to do that on the Scottish Government website."Alternatively, you can collect the tests from Covid testing centres from the afternoon or early evening."I would encourage everyone to take advantage of this offer, but I want to highlight one issue in particular today, where we arereallyencouraging people to make sure they use lateral flow testing, as appropriate."Last week, I spoke about the situation on our islands: we are keeping island communities at the same level as the rest of the country, at the moment, so that we can allow travel between island communities and the rest of Scotland."But we know that does create a risk for island communities. Many of them currently have very, very low rates of Covid and they will be welcoming visitors from parts of Scotland - which I know many of them are looking forward to - where Covid will still be circulating at a higher level and more widely."Soyou are planning to travel to an island, we do encourage you to take two lateral flow tests before you depart."The second test should be on the day that you are planning to travel and the first should be three days before you travel."That meansyou test positive, you have the chance to take a PCR test, which is more sensitive, to confirm the result before making a final decision on cancelling your visit.""So,you are planning on travelling to an island over the course of next week, it is possible to get tests from today - and I would encourage you to do that."You can find out more about how to get a test on the Scottish Government website here.

title: sperm-whale-skeleton-found-south-uist-beach-following-stranding
story: Hannah Burns, , stumbled across the giant bones- which belongto a dead sperm whale - while out walking on a South Uist beach near Stoneybridge.:WATCH: Lucky onlookers catch glimpse of Sei Whale rarely seen in Scottish watersMs Burns, who recently moved to South Uist in the Outer Hebrides, said she was "looking forward to exploring more" in the hopes of making further intriguing discoveries.She explained: "We first saw the skeleton when we were out for our dog walk and went over to investigate", she explained."Our first thought was that it was a whale because it was so big, and didnt think there was anything  that size."Credit: Hannah Burns"Im not marine expert", Hannah added, but said she "knew there had been strandings on the Outer Hebrides before."After taking incredible photographs of the find, her sister Polly Burns posted the images to social media, where they have attracted much attention.Some fans of the Loch Ness Monster have even joked the remains might belong to a relative of Nessie.Hannahs sister Polly, , wrote: ldquoMy sister has just moved to South Uist and has found this skeleton - anyone able to help with ID  Golden retriever provided for scale.Credit: Hannah BurnsHowever, Ms Burns was not was not the first to find the skeleton, which was a sperm whale that stranded last year.Uist Sea Tours wrote on Facebook in February: ldquoFirst time Irsquove been down to look at this. The long structure is about foot long and the smaller bit is foot long. Still a bit of flesh on it and a smell too.Ms Burns, who has only lived on the island for a few weeks, added: "Ive not found anything  yet but have only been living here for a few weeks - looking forward to exploring more!"

title: seeing-red-new-scottish-50-note
story: The new Bank of Scotland polymer pound note, will enter circulation in July.A new UV feature depicts a horse pulling a canal barge, representing how horses shaped the geographical layout of the Falkirk area.The new pound notes feature the poem Steam Barge, by William Muir. It was written after he saw the newly-invented steam boat passing through Scotlandrsquos Grand Canal.The new design is part of the banks ongoing bridges series of notes.The design marks a change in colour from traditional green to red.The front of the new note remains the same and portrays the Scottish novelist and poet Sir Walter Scott, alongside the image of The Mound in Edinburgh.Scottish Canals chief executive Catherine Topley said she was "delighted" that the attractions would feature on the new note.She said: "This decision by the Bank of Scotland pays homage to Scottish Canals transformation in central Scotland over the last  years."The note also complements the appearance of The Falkirk Wheel in the United Kingdoms passports, recognising its signicance to the nations infrastructure."Philip Grant, chairman of the Scottish executive committee of the Bank of Scotland, said: ldquoBank of Scotland has issued bank notes showcasing our countryrsquos rich history for more than  years. Our new pound note, with its images of the majestic Kelpies, the Falkirk Wheel and a poem by William Muir, celebrates the greatness of Scottish culture and engineering achievement. I am very proud to be a signatory on the note, in my role as Treasurer of Bank of Scotland.

title: sturgeon-insists-independent-scotland-procured-vaccine-uk-wide
story: During an online hustings event for students, the First Minister and the Scottish Conservative leader clashed over the Covid- vaccine programme ndash with MrRoss telling Ms Sturgeon ldquoyour rollout was poor.Mr Ross pointed to the lacklustre rollout of the vaccine in mainland Europe with EU nations struggling to keep pace with the programme in the UK.But the First Minister blasted Mr Ross for insinuating an independent Scotland could not procure the vaccine on a UK-wide basis.:Tories say SNPs Indyref focus would see drug deaths soarShe said: ldquoThe UK chose to procure in the way that it did, and youre saying it couldnt have done that and Scotland couldnt have chosen to do that with the other UK nations had we been a member of the EU.ldquoThat is quite simply not true.Ms Sturgeon added: "We procured the vaccine the same way we procure the flu vaccine and you dont have to tell me how many people are being vaccinated with the first dose."I spend every day overseeing the programme, so stop talking down our vaccination programme for political purposes, it is disgraceful to seek to do that."Oh dear... @AnasSarwar the grown up in the room as always. pic LyxeYlJBSpeaking to journalists today, Mr Ross insisted he was not talking down Scotlandrsquos vaccintors ndash stressing that ldquonot a single politician is undermining the outstanding effort they have put in.He added: ldquoHowever, you cannot ignore the fact that in Scotland over % of people, from yesterdayrsquos figures, have received the first dose of the vaccine and I was just looking at the European figures where the average is .%.ldquoBy any measure, we are miles ahead here in Scotland.ldquoThe fact that Nicola Sturgeon refuses to accept thatrsquos because of the procurement and development of the vaccine that the United Kingdom has taken forward is churlish, itrsquos irresponsible and the fact that she got so angry about even being questioned about that shows that I think she doesnrsquot want to accept the unquestionable benefits of the Union of the United Kingdom of delivering our way out of this pandemic through the vaccination programme.The Scottish Tory leader was pressed over the First Ministerrsquos argument that an independent Scotland could still procure vaccinations on a UK-wide basis.:Boris Johnson campaign no-show blamed on Covid despite January lockdown visitHe said: ldquoItrsquos very critical then of independent countries such as Ireland who are on .%. What have Ireland got it wrong but Nicola Sturgeon would get it right ldquoWhat are Burlgaria down at .% but Nicola Sturgeon would have got it right He added: ldquoIt is beyond belief that Nicola Sturgeon would somehow be able to do it better than all these other independent countries within the European Union.ldquoItrsquos clear that wersquove only been able to achieve this because we are part of the United Kingdom which was procuring and developing these vaccines at the early stage of the pandemic.ldquoNicola Sturgeonrsquos argument falls at the first hurdle.During the NUS hustings event, Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar was told to ldquoget off the fence by the First Minister and was told to ldquodecide which side youre on".Mr Sarwar said: ldquoI think my position is pretty clear."I like to not forget about half of the country that doesnt agree with me on the constitution because I think we need to pull out country back together."We are in a pandemic after all and , of our fellow citizens have lost their lives. Perhaps others could remember that sometimes."

title: stuc-backs-indyref2-pro-independence-majority-elected
story: The STUC congress has voted in favour of a motion stating that Holyrood should have the power to hold a referendum on Scotlandrsquos future and should not need the consent of Boris Johnson and the UK Government.The motion also states that the UK Government should not resist a second votea majority of pro-independence MSPs are elected to Holyrood at next monthrsquos election ndash along with a clear preference among the Scottish public for a re-run of the  vote.But union bosses warned that the next class of MSPs must prioritise recovery from the pandemic over constitutional issues.The STUC statement also rejects the pursuit of a supermajority for independence in the next Parliament through tactical manoeuvring ndash a case pressed by Alex Salmondrsquos Alba Party.Union leaders have warned this strategy would undermine the sovereignty of the Scottish people.:Salmond promises more courage, less caution as he launches Alba manestoSTUC general secretary, Roz Foyer, said: ldquoOur vote today has re-affirmed the right of the Scottish people to self-determination and recognised that as the central democratic institution in Scotland, our parliament should have the power to determine whether and when to hold a second referendum.ldquoWe have also made clear that any future referendum need not be confined to a binary choicea meaningful third option is developed.She added: ldquoBut we have also asserted that economic and social recovery is our priority, and that radical policy is needed to achieve that in a way that redresses current imbalances of power and wealth. We will hold to account all parties of all political colours who take their eye off that ball.ldquoAs a movement of over half a million people we naturally have ergent views on the outcome of any future referendum. We have resolved today to actively consult with our members and to play a leading role within Scottish civil society in this crucial debate.The motion has been welcomed by the SNP and the Greens but heaps pressure on Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar who earlier this week said his opposition to another independence referendum was ldquounequivocal.:Sarwar stresses unequivocal IndyRef opposition after Starmers commentsThe party has enjoyed a long-standing relationship with the trade union movement.SNP depute leader Keith Brown said: ldquoThis is a signicant and important intervention from the STUC, which proves that both Labour and the Toriesrsquo arrogant attempts to deny democracy will not stand."There is simply no democratic, electoral or moral justication for any politician to block the right of the people of Scotland to choose a better future.ldquoA post-pandemic referendum will give people in Scotland the right to decide the kind of country we should be after the current crisis, protect our NHS from the threat of post-Brexit Tory trade deals, and halt the Tories undermining of devolution through the damaging Internal Market Act.:Scottish Green election strategy accused of actively undermining independenceHe added: "Scotlands right to choose its own future is a decision that lies solely with the people of Scotland - not out-of-touch Westminster governments that we donrsquot vote for."Only giving both votes to the SNP will guarantee that Scotlandrsquos recovery from the Covid- pandemic is in Scotlandrsquos hands - not Boris Johnsonrsquos.Scottish Greens co-leader Patrick Harvie said the agreed motion ldquorecognises the fundamental right of self-determination".He added: ldquoThe STUC rightly says that Scotlandrsquos future is a matter for the people of Scotland, andthey choose to elect a parliament with a pro-independence majority then it should be for that parliament to hold a referendum.ldquoIrsquom sure many traditional Labour voters will find it incomprehensible that the Scottish Labour Partys position is at odds with this perfectly reasonable statement of democratic principles.ldquoScotlandrsquos future is at stake in this election. Thatrsquos why the Scottish Greens are asking the public to vote like our future depends on it. For bold climate action, to build a fair and green recovery, and to put Scotlandrsquos future in Scotlandrsquos hands, vote Green.Scottish Labour has been approached for comment.

title: orkney to remain in level three from april 26
story: coronavirusOrkney stays in Level Three from April , travel to mainland Scotland opensApril ,  at : pm vw, px"  Orkney is to remain in Level Three from April , and travel to the Scottish mainland will be allowed, the First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has announced.It is planned that all Scotland — including Orkney — will drop to Level Two from May , to Level One in June, and to Level Zero in #later June.#In a COVID briefing today, Tuesday, Ms Sturgeon confirmed the news, focussing on island communities like Orkney and Shetland.This follows uncertainty over whether the islands would either drop to Level Two and have no mainland Scotland travel, or to stay in Level Three and have mainland travel allowed.An island consultation was also launched by the government, asking islanders to give their opinion on the two options.Ms Sturgeon said: #I think it#s fair to say there#s no universal opinion here, so I know that neither option will please everybody.#However, based on the balance of opinion, we have decided on the latter option, aligning islands with the rest of the country for a period, so that travel and therefore parts of the economy — that so many islanders rely on — can operate more normally from April .Ms Sturgeon wanted to reassure those who wished for the islands to drop into Level Two from the end of April, that this drop is planned in around three weeks time, from May .Full story in the upcoming edition of The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: rspb dials up bird of prey search with hen harrier hotline
story: RSPB Scotland is encouraging folk in Orkney to keep their eyes peeled for one of the UK’s rarest birds of prey as theyto their breeding grounds this spring.Hen harriers are medium-sized birds of prey, similar to a buzzard but with a slightly slimmer appearance, with long wings and a long tail.Female and young hen harriers are speckled brown and cream with horizontal stripes on their tails. The most striking feature is the patch of white at their rump. Males are slightly smaller and pale grey with black wingtips. Both have a round, owl-like face.Hen harriers are the UK#s most persecuted bird of prey relative to its population size. Their Scottish population is of global importance, yet it remains far from stable largely as a result of illegal killing by humans.The RSPB’s Jenni Burrell said: “We are calling on the public to email our Hen Harrier Hotlinethey believe they’ve seen a hen harrier. This helps us build a picture of where these birds are. Please don’t hesitate to contact usyou see them # we welcome any sightings and appreciate your time.“Hen harriers are beautul and elusive raptors and, unlike peregrines and kestrels, they are rarely seen in urban environments. Soit’s perched on your fence, it’s probably a sparrowhawk,it’s in a tree by the roadside, it’s probably a kestrel or a buzzard… butit’s over rough pasture or moorland, and matches the description above, then you might have seen a hen harrier.“Sadly hen harriers are a long way from reaching a healthy, self-sustaining population, and this is largely down to persecution by humans. Particularly where land is managed for the purpose of driven grouse shooting, natural predators like hen harriers can be viewed as pests and, despite being legally protected, the shooting, trapping and poisoning of hen harriers is a serious and ongoing problem.”If you think you’ve seen a hen harrier, you are asked to email henharriers@rspb.org.uk and to include the date, time, location grid reference and a description of the bird.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. had ldquonothing to conceal and would be willing to share ldquoall the details with the Commons.Speaking in the House, Sir Keir told MPs: ldquoThe Prime Minister is fixing tax breaks for his friends, the Chancellor is pushing the Treasury to help Lex Greensill, the Health Secretary is meeting Greensill for drinks, and David Cameron is texting anybody who will reply.ldquoEvery day there are new itrsquos all on his watch.ldquoWith this scandal now firmly centred on him, how on earth does he expect people to believe that he is the person to clean this mess up Mr Johnson replied: ldquoIrsquoll tell you why this Government is doing the right thing at the right time, because the dference between us and the Labour Party is, Irsquom afraid, staringly obvious and we get on with taking the tough decisions to protect the people of this country and to take our country forward ndash uniting and levelling up.Mr Johnson defended the Governmentrsquos procurement during the pandemic and criminal justice reforms, adding: ldquoCaptain Hindsight snipes continually from the sidelines, this Government gets on with delivering on the peoplersquos priorities.Earlier, Sir Keir asked: ldquoWhat does Park on Wednesday.Experts estimate the UK may have lost at least % of its seagrasses since , % since the s, and that the losses over longer time spans may be as high as %.Seagrass meadows provide homes for young fish and protected creatures such as seahorses and stalked jellyfish.Were planting Englands BIGGEST EVER seagrass restoration site in Plymouth Sound National Marine Park as part of the @EULIFERemedies project!#Weve deployed , biodegradable seed bags  , seedling bags onto the seabed to grow! #saveourseabed#https:t.co kqCDk pic qRdbqgonmdash Ocean Conservation TrustApril , The plant rainforests, and while it only covers .% of the seafloor, it absorbs % of the oceanrsquos carbon each year.The last of , seagrass seed bags and , seedling bags will be planted in Plymouth as part of a four-year project aiming to plant a total of eight hectares of seagrass meadows.The process involves dropping biodegradable hessian bags, containing  seeds in a nutrient rich sediment, down a plastic tube onto the seafloor up to  metres below.Within three weeks the seagrass will break through the bag which will break down itself in five weeks.In a year the plants will have matured and researchers will e down to see how it is growing.Four hectares will be in Plymouth Sound and four hectares in the Solent Maritime Special Area of Conservation.Dr Emma Nolan, seagrass cultivation officer at the Ocean Conservation Trust, said: ldquoSeagrass is a super plant, it traps carbon from the atmosphere up to  times more efficiently than the rainforest, capturing carbon in its sediment.Mark Parry, development officer at the Ocean Conservation Trust, said the project is sort of like a wildflower meadow for the sea.He added: ldquoWithin the marine environment you get animals coming in and recruitment of dferent marine le quite quickly.ldquoSo we are hoping that when we kickstart this process and our seeds grow, then we get all of the associated benefits with it quite quickly.ldquoOne of the big things at the moment is about blue carbon, and really thatrsquos just carbon that is stored by the sea ndash so we could be part of that carbon cycle.To deploy , biodegradable bags of seagrass seed  seedlings on the sea floor, we first had to pack them with sediment!We couldnrsquot have achieved this without the help of our amazing volunteers! Thank you to everyone involved!#saveourseabed pic IPZlMMktFSmdash Ocean Conservation TrustApril , He added: ldquoWe are looking to restore four hectares in this area.ldquoHistorically, could it be larger  We donrsquot have a record for larger areas of it.ldquoBut yes, this is the first time on record that the eastern side of Plymouth Sound will have shown an abundant, healthy, seagrass bed.Dr Nolan told the PA news agency: ldquoTo think that this could potentially be self-sustaining,what we do works and it starts to reproduce and regrow itself, thenyou restore four hectares, that could become eight, which could become  ndash that is the dream.ldquoBut I think there is a lot of work to do before getting to that position.Mr Parry said the project had only been possible because of all the hard work of the partners in the LIFE Recreation ReMEDIES project.He added: ldquoThese events have taken over  months of planning and include a combination of volunteers who have visited the National Marine Aquarium creating our planting units and our e volunteers. vw,vw,px, px"Seed bags sitting on the seabed ldquoThis truly is a community effort.The LIFE Recreation ReMEDIES project is being led by Natural England, with the planting being carried out by project partner the Ocean Conservation Trust.Seagrass is delicate and can be damaged by activities such as the anchoring, mooring and launching of leisure boats, as well as other shore- and water-based activities.Therefore, as well as planting new seagrass meadows, the project is working to protect existing ones by helping recreational users to minimise impacts on these sensitive habitats.Natural England and ReMEDIES partners plan to extend the benefits of this work beyond the UK to assist with international marine recovery efforts.
